title: Patrice Evra opens up on racism row with Luis Suarez as Jamie Carragher apologises
text:
Patrice Evra admits feeling 'sad' for Luis Suarez in the wake of their racism row as Jamie Carragher apologised for the t-shirts Liverpool wore in support of the striker.

Suarez served an eight-match ban eight years ago after racially abusing Evra during a match between Liverpool and Manchester United at Anfield in October 2011.

The Uruguayan then failed to shake his opponent's hand in the return match at Old Trafford later in the season.

Former Manchester United defender Patrice Evra was a guest on Monday Night Football

Evra recounted the racism row with Liverpool striker Luis Suarez from eight years ago

And Evra opened up on the whole period during Monday Night Football, admitting that he can't call Suarez a racist, insisting he just used some racist words.

He said of the failed handshake episode: 'It was unbelievable. All the week, people asking are you going to shake his hand? I was frustrated, I wanted people to talk about the game.

'My Mum asked me and I said "Mummy I say I'm someone who will forgive, I will shake his hand no matter what" and he made a mistake - I won't go on holiday with him.

'When he didn't I was like "what's wrong with that guy, he makes himself worse". I'm feeling sad for him.'

Evra admits to feeling 'sad' for Suarez after the failed handshake at Old Trafford in 2012

Liverpool wore t-shirts in support of Suarez in the warmup for a match at Wigan that season

Liverpool's players were widely criticised for supporting Suarez after he had been charged

Liverpool courted controversy when they and then-manager Kenny Dalglish wore 'Suarez 7' t-shirts in the warm-up for a clash at Wigan, in support of their player.

Evra branded the incident 'ridiculous'.

He added: 'Even for the club you put it in danger. You always have to support your players, but this was after the ban. What message are you sending to the world when you do that?'

Fellow pundit Carragher, who was Liverpool vice-captain at the time and in the squad, admitted: 'We made a massive mistake, that was obvious'.

Jamie Carragher, Liverpool vice-captain at the time, has apologised for the episode

'It was an evening game, we travelled on the day, team meeting in lunch. Kenny Dalglish or Steve Clarke said: "Are you wearing the shirts?"

'That's the first I'd heard of it. I think that was people who were close to Luis in the dressing room. Maybe I look at myself now I didn't have the courage to say... I don't think everyone at the club thought what we were doing was right.

'As a family, football club, your first reaction is to support them and that's wrong.

'I'm not condoning Suarez, it was wrong, for clubs that is the first reaction. And we got it wrong, apologies.'
description: Patrice Evra admits feeling 'sad' for Luis Suarez in the wake of their racism row as Jamie Carragher apologised for the t-shirts Liverpool wore in support of the striker.
